subject: Re: [junit] method testing?
msgSnippet: ... Classical testing theory knows the concept of oracles , i.e. programs which will compute the expected output of a test for a given (dynamically) computed
messageBody:
> i have read many examples of using asserEquals(expected, theResult).
>
> mostly in those examples the expected is already determined. what if
> i can't determine it first???? i want to test whether my methods work
> for all possible inputs.
>
> say i have method : trimA(String s) that replaces all occurrences of
> A/a with nothing. of course if the input is BaB the expected is BB,
> BaaaaB still the same. However, i couldn't specify all the possible
> outputs right?
>
> so how to do method testing?

Classical testing theory knows the concept of "oracles", i.e. programs which
will compute the expected output of a test for a given (dynamically)
computed input. Bob Binder has dedicated a whole chapter of his oo-testing
book to this topic.

However, in cases like yours, building an oracle would basically mean to
duplicate the algorithm of your trimA() method which is not a reasonable
thing to do for a developer testing her own code. Proceed as suggested in
another post: Choose a couple of examples which make you feel comfortable
with your implementation. In most cases testing is the art of finding the
crucial set of examples.

In a sense test-driven development is about finding the minimal (or
reasonably small) crucial set of examples.

Johannes
